nodes.bodyText: This is for testing purposes only right? If not should this be atomic, or locked when modified, as this isn't completely thread-safe right now.
It is only for testing purposes. I probably should add a clarifying comment though.
Would it be better to move the interface and class below to their own files?
Leaving them in this file is fine, I just didn't have a complete understanding of this when I wrote the comment.

Is this planned to be used in the public API? If so, instead of maintaining context in this static helper class should a new overload to each API be added which accepts this interface? That way this class remains thread safe and stateless as expected with a static helper class.

This is not planned to be a part of the public API. The reason I wrote this interface was so we wouldn't have to mock the static methods in Android's Base64 class. This is due to a couple of reasons:

Unfortunately, we cannot use Java's version of this class since it only works with a higher Android version than our supported minimum.
We cannot access the Android framework's classes in unit tests, which are only accessible when running on the actual operating system on an emulator or physical device. Unit tests run on the local JVM.
Is a wrapper being set as Base64 isn't consistent between Android versions or between devices?

The reason to set this here is that we cannot call Android framework's classes like Base64 from unit tests and we cannot use Java's Base64 class because that's only available at a later Android version. To get around this and not use something like PowerMock to mock static methods like Base64.encode(), I created the Base64Wrapper interface. Normally it will always be set to Base64Android and for unit tests it will be set to Base64Stub.
Any reason that assertEquals can't be used here? It would allow for the suppression to be removed.
There is no reason not to use assertEquals. I must have missed it. Thanks for pointing it out!
Same question
See answer above.
Does Base64Url's equals overload compare against the String representation? If so could this be assertNull(base64Url.toString())?
You are right, we don't use the String representation of Base64Url for comparisons so this can be made to use assertNull.
Same comment as notEqualTo_nullObject.
Here we can just use assertNotEquals.
I think some tests should be added that use non-null, right now this will get good code coverage but is missing real world scenarios.
Based on the test names, it actually seems I was planning to write the non-null tests but somehow got busy with something else and missed them.
I will correct and add tests that check for the positive scenarios when we have a non-null source and non-empty string.
Unless we have overridden the hash code method I wouldn't eagerly test this as it is dependent on the underlying JVM and has the potential for collisions.
We did override it in our DateTimeRfc1123 class, however, it just uses the hashCode method in OffsetDateTime. I think I will remove this test for the time being.
Actually, after digging around on the internet, I think I will take the approach showed here.
assertEquals?
Agreed.
Same comment as the other hashCode test.
See comment above for the same question.
How strong is the guarantee that the backing Map for ExandableStringEnum will return a collection where the elements are ordered by how they are added?

There is no guarantee since this is not a LinkedHashSet, so I think the best course of action would be to cast the Collection returned by values() to a HashSet and see if the values we are looking for are contained there.
assertNotNull?
Agreed.
